content:
where  $\mathbf{m}_{\mathrm{P}}$  is the magnetic moment of the dipole P.

Equilibrium is stable when  $\mathbf{m}_{\mathrm{Q}}$  is parallel to  $\mathbf{B}_{\mathrm{P}}$ , and unstable when it is anti-parallel to  $\mathbf{B}_{\mathrm{P}}$ .

# EXAMPLE 5.2

For instance for the configuration  $\mathbf{Q}_3$  for which  $\mathbf{Q}$  is along the perpendicular bisector of the dipole  $\mathbf{P}$ , the magnetic moment of  $\mathbf{Q}$  is parallel to the magnetic field at the position 3. Hence  $\mathbf{Q}_3$  is stable. Thus,

(a)  $\mathrm{PQ}_1$  and  $\mathrm{PQ}_2$
(b) (i)  $\mathrm{PQ}_3$ ,  $\mathrm{PQ}_6$  (stable); (ii)  $\mathrm{PQ}_5$ ,  $\mathrm{PQ}_4$  (unstable)
(c)  $\mathrm{PQ}_6$
summary: Explanation of the magnetic stability and equilibrium of configurations involving dipole moment and magnetic field at different positions.
hypothetical_questions: Could you describe the magnetic stability and equilibrium at different positions?
What are the stable and unstable configurations involving a dipole moment and magnetic field?
